title: How has the proportion of people receiving diagnostic tests within 6 and 13 weeks changed?
analysis_commentary:
Diagnostic waiting times are strongly linked to treatment waiting times as in order to access timely and appropriate treatment, you must first have diagnostic tests. Recognising the importance of this link, the Department of Health introduced a 6 week diagnostic wait as a target from March 2008. This was to ensure people would not be waiting longer than 6 weeks for a diagnostic test following referral from a GP. It was planned that the introduction a target for diagnostic waiting times would support achievement of the longer 18 week referral to treatment target.

The proportion of diagnostic tests where patients waiting longer than 6 weeks or 13 weeks has fallen dramatically since March 2008, when the 6-week target was introduced. Since then the proportion waiting longer than these targets has been fairly steady, always less than 5%. In June 2010, central performance management of targets was relaxed and we can see an increase in waits over 6 weeks recorded around May 2011, though this fell later in that year. More recently, since November 2013, the proportion waiting more than 6 weeks has been increasing and was 2.2% in April 2014.
